awd_titl_txt: Fostering Connections between Macroscopic, Submicroscopic, and Representational Levels Using Analogical Reasoning in the Chemistry Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists and science educators have emphasized the vital role that reasoning with analogies plays in innovation, making new discoveries, and advancing science. Chemists are adept at using such analogical reasoning to make connections between observations that can be made with the senses (macroscopic level), the behavior of submicroscopic particles such as atoms and molecules, and the various representations used in chemistry. However, many chemistry students struggle with making these connections in college courses, and this creates a barrier to their learning. The CORE learning cycle (Chemical Observations Representation Experimentation) is designed to provide an environment where students can develop their analogical reasoning skills in a sequence that mirrors the process of experimentation and discovery. A main goal of CORE is to support the development of strong analogical reasoning skills in a way that fosters the connections between macroscopic, submicroscopic and representational domains. Another key goal is to foster the integration of strong analogical reasoning into the experimental design process and in construction of scientific arguments. This project will investigate how students use analogical reasoning in constructing scientific arguments related to chemistry laboratory work and how repeated exposure to CORE experiments influence students' abilities to coordinate their ideas across macroscopic, submicroscopic, and representational levels. Thus, it has the potential to provide undergraduate students with the skills needed to be successful in participating in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) in the future.

This NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE: EHR) project will gather critical evidence to better understand how to develop undergraduate chemistry students' analogical reasoning skills and help students coordinate ideas across macroscopic, submicroscopic, and representational levels. The research will investigate student participation in CORE learning cycles over a series of five CORE experiments. The underlying frameworks embedded in the CORE learning cycle are based on Structure Mapping Theory and the Teaching-with-Analogy model. Two research questions will be addressed: (1) How do students use analogical reasoning in constructing scientific arguments related to chemistry laboratory work? and (2) How does repeated exposure to CORE experiments influence students' abilities to coordinate ideas across macroscopic, submicroscopic, and representational levels? Students' laboratory work will be analyzed to assess their understanding of analogical reasoning, their appreciation for the limitations of analogies, and the quality of students' scientific arguments. An adaptation of Toulmin's model of argumentation will be used to assess the quality of students' scientific arguments. The three-year project will involve 32 student participants per year and will engage a K-12 science teacher each summer to adapt CORE experiments for K-12 classrooms. The project will contribute new knowledge to inform both science education researchers and STEM instructors about ways to foster analogical reasoning skills and coordination of ideas across macroscopic, submicroscopic and representational levels.

por.por_cntn:
The project, Fostering Connections between Macroscopic, Submicroscopic, and Representational Levels Using Analogical Reasoning in the Chemistry Laboratory, evaluated the CORE experimental approach in a laboratory setting. CORE (Chemical Observations, Representation, Experimentation) is a scaffolded learning strategy, formulated as a 3-phase learning cycle to help students develop analogical reasoning skills. A goal is to have students learn how to create representations to connect macroscopic and submicroscopic domains of knowledge. Scientists and science educators have emphasized the vital role that forming representation has in makingscientific discoveries. Forming representation refers to a particular type of reasoning process that considers experimental evidence andemploys analogical reasoning to make comparisons between macroscopic and submicroscopic domains. However, students have difficulty in making such connections. To address this problem, CORE places students at the center of the inquiry, where they:

  • Make chemical observations (phase 1), 
  • Carry out specific activities to help them generate ideas about comparing macroscopic to submicroscopic domains of knowledge (phase 2), and 
  • Design experiments (phase 3). 

Another important design element in CORE is to have students reflect on their chemical results in a lab report. 

Students were administered a survey to gauge prior inquiry experience, using 5 dimensions of inquiry (questions, evidence, explanations, connecting explanations to scientific knowledge, justifying explanations). This survey was used to compose cohorts that mirror the level of experience of the class as a whole. Correlation between student responses and how students justified their choices and interviews were used in the process of validating the survey. 

Student data from lab work (analog and target worksheets) and lab reports were the major corpus for analysis. About 200 students in 3 cohorts (30 to 60 students each) participated in the project. Qualitative content analysis, structure mapping theory, and analogical reasoning and limitation frames previously published, were utilized for analysis. 

During CORE labs, students use worksheets to generate ideas by making comparisons between macroscopic and submicroscopic domains. The original worksheet had students consider similarities and differences between the analog (macroscopic entity) and target (submicroscopic phenomenon). While students in cohort 1 (n = 12) generated many ideas that could be used to form representation, words associated with the submicroscopic, e.g. bond, occurred with a fairly low frequency. A revision was made to the worksheet to include a second comparison of the differences, i.e. going in the reverse direction from the macroscopic to submicroscopic. Students in cohort 2 (n = 12) using this 2nd generation worksheet showed improvements in the types of ideas they generated, including a 3-fold increase in use of words like bond. 

A major research question was how students use analogical reasoning. Analysis of lab reports after performing a CORE experiment show that most students use analogical reasoning but it occurs only in certain places. To analyze location of content in lab reports, the following was tracked: procedures (P), calculations (C), chemical observations (O), sense making (SM), and analogical reasoning (AR). The patterns from 128 CORE lab reports (cohorts 1 and 2), show a high percentages containing AR, but mostly in the analysis section and introduction. However, not all occurrences of AR lead to representation or connection. A pattern analysis shows that when students used AR with O and SM, they are much more likely to form representation and successfully make connections. Another key finding is that some students use representation in multiple ways in the same lab report. Overall, a majority of students conducting CORE lab experiments show one or more instances in lab reports where AR is used with O and SM and connections occur.

Analysis of worksheets and lab reports provide insight into the driving forces of how and why students make connections between domains of knowledge. For many years it has been well established that students have difficulty in making such connections. However, it is just as firmly established that experts utilize such connections routinely to understand experimental results. What separates the novice from expert in this regard? Advanced content knowledge alone appears insufficient, since many upper-level chemistry majors still have difficulty. Both science ed and chemistry researchers have suggested that ?process? is paramount, but have not identified many supports and strategies to help students be successful. The scaffolding present in a CORE lab experiment was examined to understand what processes students use to formulate connections. This examination led to the development of a new CORE theoretical frame. 

Lab reports from a non-CORE lab experiment performed by cohort 1 students (n=18) after exposure to several CORE labs were also examined showing that 61% of students used analogical reasoning. Subsequently, CORE-like scaffolding was added to this lab for cohort 2 (n = 18) which showed a modest gain in use of AR reasoning to 89%. 

Several K-12 teachers participated in learning about CORE labs, creating modified CORE labs, and some were performed by students in middle school.
